Comment: The case studies look at a lot of possible attributions like this, yes -- and it also includes cases other than those about individuals, like companies, animals, countries, markets, hedge funds, etc.  What it does is demonstrate how many other (unpredictable) parameters factor into these kinds of events and dispells common post-hoc misattributions we often apply because of the things we _know_ and our failure to consider all the things we don't know or can't know.  These kinds of black swan moments aren't just about the things that make billionaires -- it's relative to the actor or observer. For example, it could be something like you get a job that kickstarts your career in a new field or industry that happens to become lucrative in the future for one reason or another. If you never job-hopped, maybe you would have never found that job. These events with inordinate impact can also be negative.

Comment: Some of the more fascinating encounters I've had have been whenever I've suggested to wealthy people that their success has been attributed in any way to chance. Some folks will belligerently, doggedly insist that it was only their own choices and hard work--and, at least in my experience (albeit perhaps unsurprisingly), those folks are also the ones who are likely to be selfish, miserly, and arrogant. After all, if you think your success is entirely your own fault, it's not a long leap to conclude also that the failure of others must be due to their laziness, stupidity, or some other less-than-ness.  By contrast, some of the successful people I'm closest to will cheerfully volunteer that their successes were also largely a matter of chance. That understanding tends to make you humble and more compassionate, since the fortune that made you can just as easily unmake you. I know a great many people who struggle financially who are brilliant but whose ship just never came in despite their best efforts, or who used to be on an upward trajectory before a medical bill thwarted them, an investor backed out, or their industry evaporated. So much of life is beyond our control.  I think understanding the role that chance plays in success and failure is a kind of enlightenment. Once you see how little control you have on which opportunities you encounter and don't encounter, and which bets pay off and don't pay off, it's easy to want to provide those opportunities for others when you can, to be generous when you're ahead, and to extend a hand to others trying to climb alongside you.
